**The Founding of the Lingji Palace in the Capital and the Erection of Its Stele**

In the fifteenth year of the Yongle reign, *dingyou* (1417), the Emperor decreed Minister Fang Bin and Commander Lin Guan to construct the Lingji Temporary Palace within the western part of Beijing’s inner city. To its east and west were built the *Qinmu Zhusheng* Halls. The flanking corridors housed the generals and their retinues, all modeled after the ancestral palace in Fujian. The work was completed on the fifteenth day of the ninth month that year. Later, due to negligence in maintaining its virtue, the palace fell into disrepair. In the autumn of the tenth year of *yimao* (1435), the Emperor again decreed the Ministry of Works and the eunuchs to expand and rebuild upon the original foundation, refining its scale and grandeur. On the fifteenth day of the first month in the first year of the Zhengtong reign, *bingchen* (1436), a stele was erected, and the rites of sacrifice were elevated beyond those of former times.

**Imperial Stele for the Restoration of the Hong’en Lingji Palace**

The Lingji Palace in the capital was established by Our Imperial Great-Grandfather, the Taizong Wen Emperor. His achievements surpassed those of antiquity, his benevolence blanketed the realm, and the flourishing of his governance remains unmatched. Yet even in his time, when Heaven and humanity responded in harmony and the hundred spirits manifested their efficacy, their hidden aid and manifest blessings—impossible to conceal—demanded reverent worship. Thus, in the *kun* quarter of the Forbidden City, this palace was built to enshrine the Two Xu Immortals. This follows the *Zhou* principle of "ordering all without omission," not merely for the sake of prayer and supplication.

The deities were descendants of the Southern Tang during the Five Dynasties. The elder was named Xu Zhizheng, and the younger, Xu Zhie. Their lineage, titles, meritorious deeds, and the details of their responsive manifestations were already recorded in the stele erected by Our Imperial Father during his restoration of the palace. Upon examining their lives, We observe: the deities’ innate endowments were both heroic and peerless, and they shared a single heart in their love of goodness. When stationed in Jinling, they soothed refugees, lightened taxes, and won the people’s reverence. Later, upon receiving orders to campaign in Min, they abhorred warfare. Wherever they went, they pacified and comforted the people, who surrendered at the mere rumor of their approach. Even those who rebelled in the mountains were dealt with by punishing only the ringleaders, while the rest were pardoned. Thus, the people held them in deep gratitude, erecting a shrine in their honor at the foot of Jinao Peak to express their devotion. Their benevolence had truly taken root in the hearts of the people.

Though the deities later departed this world, their spiritual essence did not fade. They descended in spirit upon this shrine, their divine brush and immortal slips leaving wondrous traces, and the people’s affairs grew ever more orderly. In times of flood, drought, pestilence, wind, fire, locusts, or other calamities, prayers were answered without fail. Those in dire peril, without heirs, or embroiled in battle who called upon the deities found their pleas met—countless instances defy enumeration.

From the Kaiyun era of the Later Jin, through the Jiaxi era of the Song when a temple was established and a name bestowed, to the Yuanzhen era of the Yuan when they were enfeoffed with titles such as *Jinque* and *Yueque* (Golden and Jade Towers) and honored as *Great Immortals* and *Supreme Immortals*, their numinous power had long been renowned in the region, though their glory had not yet reached its full splendor. In the fifteenth year of Our Imperial Great-Grandfather’s reign, he fell gravely ill, and no medicine proved effective. Someone spoke of the deities’ miraculous efficacy, and so he prayed with utmost sincerity. Indeed, a profound response manifested: through divine talismans and wondrous remedies, he recovered fully, the ancestral altars were secured, and the people found solace. The deities’ merit shone resplendently. Thus, grand and solemn rites of gratitude were established, sparing no effort in their magnificence.

Their titles were expanded with layered honors, their fame and virtue intertwined. The temple in Min was grandly renovated, and seasonal sacrifices, annual vestments, and attendants for sweeping were provided. In the capital, a temporary shrine was erected for their worship, bestowed the name *Hong’en Lingji* (Vast Grace and Numinous Aid)—this very palace. The invocations and sacrificial rites were unparalleled in their splendor. From then on, the deities’ awe-inspiring power blazed in the heavens, as radiant as the sun and moon, as manifest as wind and thunder. The four directions and ten thousand lands all gazed in reverence and veneration. The blessings they bestowed defy description—how magnificent!

Since then, successive sagely emperors have further honored their worship. In the early Zhengtong era, Our Imperial Father, the Yingzong Rui Emperor, once again restored the palace and elevated their titles to *True Lords*. Over fifty years have passed since then. Now, We have inherited the great enterprise of Our Ancestors, sheltered under the deities’ protective shade, and deeply reflect that Our devotion to their veneration may yet be insufficient. Thus, in the autumn of the *yisi* year of the Chenghua reign (1485), We commanded ministers within and without the court to oversee the work, gather materials, expand the original foundation, and add halls and corridors, ensuring utmost solidity and refinement. The following year, *bingwu* (1486), the project was completed: glazed tiles and gilded ornaments gleamed brilliantly, and the imperial regalia and ritual implements were meticulously arranged.

Thereupon, We bestowed exalted titles: the elder was named *Supreme Emperor of the Nine Heavens, Golden Tower, Grand Overseer of the Celestial Chiefs, Vast Grace and Numinous Aid, Benevolent and Illustrious*; the younger, *Supreme Emperor of the Nine Heavens, Jade Tower, Grand Overseer of the Celestial Warriors, Vast Grace and Numinous Aid, Benevolent and Vastly Serene*. This follows the Daoist scriptures, which state they originally held office in the Dipper Palace. The titles of their parents and consorts were also elevated in accordance with their former honors. A propitious day was chosen for the sacrificial announcement, and their numinous radiance shone forth. Our heart was gratified, and all agreed that this occasion demanded a record.

We reflect: the qi of Heaven and Earth is most numinous and unfathomable—this is the nature of the divine. Humans receive this qi to live. Those who, in life, possess wisdom, uprightness, and the ability to establish meritorious deeds for eternity, and in death, continue to manifest their numinous efficacy, bestowing boundless blessings—these, too, are called divine. Truly, they aid the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth and assist in their transformative nurturance. To enjoy grand titles, receive honorifics, and be enshrined for a hundred generations, enduring as long as Heaven and Earth—who could say this is undeserved?

Now that the deities’ abode has been renewed, their dragon chariots and cloud banners ascend and descend in stately procession, and fragrant wine and jade mats await their morning and evening enjoyment. May they silently regulate the transformative mechanisms of Heaven and Earth and universally bestow their vast blessings upon all living beings. Above, may they protect Our Sagely Mother with ten thousand years of longevity; in the middle, may they safeguard Our person, the heir apparent, and the imperial line for a hundred generations; below, may they grant ministers and the people the blessings of wealth, longevity, and well-being.

May the house and state endure ten thousand years of glory, and may the deities forever receive boundless offerings in return—this is Our deepest wish. Thus, We carve this stone and inscribe a poem:

Heaven-born, Huang Yu became a deity,
Mastering creation’s work, riding wind and cloud.
None below compare in aiding and benefiting all—
Who but these Two Perfected Ones could match such grace?
Born in the Five Dynasties, their talents unmatched,
They jointly governed key regions, laboring in pacification and tour.
First they crushed rebellion, purging foul vapors,
Yet spared those coerced, nurturing them with benevolence.
Their earnest kindness and love lingered among the people,
And on the southern slope of Mount Ao, their temple still stands.
Their numinous responses, sudden and wondrous, defy full recounting:
Prayers for drought brought rain; floods cleared at their behest.
They drove off locusts, extinguished fires, averted peril and ruin—
For a hundred years, their divine power has only grown more vibrant.
Alas! When Our August Ancestor fell gravely ill,
A hundred remedies failed, and the deities were consulted.
They bestowed talismanic medicine, boundlessly wondrous,
And upon taking it, his illness vanished in an instant.
Thus, rites of gratitude were elevated, the temple’s form renewed,
And honorific titles were conferred with solemn ceremony.
Successive sagely rulers continued these offerings without cease,
Morning incense and evening silk—how earnest their devotion!
We have borne the great mandate for over two decades,
And time and again, the deities’ protection has enabled Our reverent sacrifices.
Now the palace halls are repaired, rituals refined,
Majestic and resplendent, their honored place restored.
Auspicious mists and propitious vapors coil like dragons,
While manifold blessings descend in profusion.
May they guard this court for a thousand myriad springs,
And aid Us in extending blessings to posterity.
May they universally bestow upon the Four Seas longevity and wealth in equal measure—
For the deities’ supreme numen, their blessings ever flourish.
This inscription shall proclaim their glory forever, never to fade.
Composed in the twenty-second year of the Chenghua reign.

By decree: Eunuchs of the Inner Palace, Huang Shun and Chen Gui; Grand Guardian of the Heir Apparent and Marquis of Dingxi, Jiang Wan; Junior Guardian of the Heir Apparent and Minister of Works, Liu Zhao.

The Lingji Palace, built in the reign of Our Ancestors, is the place where the Two Perfected Ones of the Golden and Jade Towers are venerated. Since ascending the throne, We have repeatedly received the deities’ protection and dispatched officials to present offerings in gratitude. All have reported that the temple’s halls and storerooms are too cramped to befit their station. Each time We hear this, Our heart cannot rest. We hold that the Son of Heaven is the master of the hundred deities, and the worship of deities is the state’s great affair. How could We tolerate such a state for their abode?

Recently, We commanded Eunuch Wei Xing to inspect the site, and his findings matched the reports. Thus, We resolved to undertake a grand renovation. Drawing from the inner treasury’s gold and silk, and mobilizing the capital’s garrison troops and skilled artisans from the supervisory bureaus, We now issue this decree to Huang Shun, Chen Gui, Jiang Wan, and Liu Zhao, entrusting you with oversight of the project. The halls, corridors, side chambers, and walls must surpass their former scale. The statues, ritual vessels, and decorative paintings shall be entrusted to Wei Xing’s supervision, crafted according to proper standards and reported in due order.

You must carefully assess the quantity of materials required, ensuring their use is clear and without waste. The labor of artisans and workers must be balanced, neither overburdened nor idle, to prevent resentment. Strictly discipline the military overseers and artisan foremen, forbidding deceit or malpractice that might hinder the work. Should any violate these orders, they shall be punished according to the severity of their offense, or sent for trial and punishment, or reported in detail for Our disposition.

Having received this commission, you must collaborate wholeheartedly and exhaust your efforts, so that all may gladly contribute to the work, and every phase be sturdy and finely wrought. Only then can it accord with Our reverence for the divine and invite the convergence of abundant blessings—universally bestowed upon the state and endlessly upon ministers and people.

You shall respectfully uphold this decree, and not neglect it. Thus decreed.

On the twenty-fourth day of the seventh month in the twenty-first year of the Chenghua reign, under the imperial seal, the Emperor decrees and instructs all officials, military personnel, commoners, and persons of every rank:

Since ascending the throne, We have reverently upheld the worship of all deities enshrined in the ritual canon. How much more so for the Two August Emperors of the Golden and Jade Towers—whose temples were established and sacrifices offered by Our imperial great-forefather, the Taizong Wen Emperor—must Our devotion be all the more meticulous.

As the temple halls had grown humble and worn, We allocated funds, selected materials, and set deadlines, commanding ministers both within and beyond the court to supervise their reconstruction. After years of labor, the work is now complete. Its layout is as follows:

At the center stand the two main halls of the Mysterious Capital and Purple Palace, front and rear. Between them lies a traversing hall, with a pavilion before the rear hall. To the left and right are the Halls of the Boundless and the Spiritually Manifest. Arrayed before and behind, east and west, are the four halls of Majestic Emptiness, Illuminated Revelation, Manifest Blessing, and Lofty Mystery, each flanked by painted corridors.

Before the halls stands the Great Portal of Manifest Majesty, with two side gates to the east and west. Four stele pavilions, two bell-and-drum towers, and two glazed-brick paper-offering towers stand in front. Further ahead is the Celestial Pivot Gate, also with side gates to the east and west. Beyond lies the mountain gate, inscribed *Hong’en Lingji Palace*. Flanking it are side gates, within which stand two cloud-board and bell pavilions, two banner poles, two well pavilions, two gatehouses, two divine storehouses, and one kitchen.

The Dharma hall, Daoist quarters, and abbot’s chambers, along with their eastern and western wings, total over three hundred and fifty bays. The entire complex is encircled by a sturdy wall, measuring eighty-three zhang and five chi in length, and fifty-seven zhang and eight chi in breadth.

Outside the mountain gate, the *Penglai* and *Langyuan* archways stand facing each other to the east and west. To the south, a high wall extends approximately fifty-seven zhang. Beyond this wall lies the *Peach Blossom Spring of Lingji Hall*, with its thatched halls and auxiliary chambers, also enclosed by a wall.

All ritual banners, pennants, liturgical instruments, and furnishings required for worship are now fully prepared. This is truly sufficient to honor the luminous spirits of the Two Emperors in heaven and to fulfill Our duty of continuing the reverent devotion of Our imperial great-forefather.

We hereby issue this decree for its protection and appoint the eunuch Wei Xing to inspect the site regularly. He shall supervise the resident clergy, ensuring that the assigned households maintain constant sweeping to keep the premises spotless. All persons are strictly forbidden from entering carelessly, lest they show disrespect or cause damage. Livestock must not be released within the grounds, nor may any act of violence, bullying of the Daoist community, or theft of ritual implements be tolerated.

The nine qing and seventy-four mu of land in Jiahe Village, Wanping County—granted during the Xuande reign—shall remain under the temple’s management to provide for incense and offerings. No one may encroach upon it. Those who violate these orders shall face punishment according to the severity of their offense: minor infractions will be met with disciplinary measures, while grave violations will be reported for trial and prosecution, with no pardon granted.

Let this be known.

**Prayer Text for the Imperial Sacrifice**

On the fourth day of the eleventh month, *dingwei*, in the cyclical year *gengxu*, of the sixteenth year of the Yongle reign (16 November 1418), the Emperor respectfully offers sacrifice to the **Perfected Lords of Vast Grace, Sovereigns of the Nine Heavens**:

**Great Immortal of the Golden Portal of the Nine Heavens, Illuminator of the Dao, Attainer of Virtue, Manifest in Wondrous Efficacy, Vast in Salvation, Pure and Subtle, Penetrating the Mysteries, Void and Marvelous, Compassionate and Benevolent, Protector of the State and Shelter of the People**;

**Supreme Immortal of the Jade Portal of the Nine Heavens, Propagator of Transformation, Upholder of the Teachings, Radiant in Spirit, Boundless in Aid, Lofty and Luminous, Vast and Serene, Profound and Tranquil, Marvelously Responsive, Benevolent and Merciful, Assistant to the State and Guardian of the People**.

The prayer declares:

O Perfected Ones, your Dao is wondrous, your virtue profound, your merits towering, your deeds illustrious. Enthroned among the Supreme Immortals, you preside over the Nine Heavens, transcending the sacred and entering the numinous. You propagate divine blessings, assist the state, and succor all beings.

Recently, We fell gravely ill, and though myriad remedies were tried, none proved efficacious. Yet, by your turning of the wheel of transformation and your silent protection, you stood by Us day and night. You bestowed sacred talismans and dispensed the wondrous medicines of celestial physicians, reviving the dying and restoring the stricken. Thus, this enfeebled body, once perilously close to ruin, was swiftly stabilized; this deep-seated malady, once entrenched, was wholly dispelled, and health was restored.

In reverence, We contemplate your virtue—vast as heaven, deep as earth.

Deeply engraved upon Our heart and bones, how could We dare forget? Now, with grand offerings of the finest sacrifice, fragrant silks, and seasonal robes, We come before the Divine to render thanks. May you deign to accept and witness Our sincerest devotion, partaking of these offerings.

Our Imperial Father, the Grand Progenitor Emperor, received the Mandate of Heaven, governing the vast realm. Deeply mindful of the arduous burden We bear, We have yet to fully repay the debt of life bestowed. Yet, as They have long since ascended, We reflect...

Where Their ascent and descent seem ever-present, We now undertake offerings and exaltations, specially extending Our grief and longing. Considering the vastness of the Four Seas, the teeming multitudes of people and creatures—all equally embraced by the vast generative power of the Great Creation—We feel gratitude and reliance upon the Mysterious Heavens that govern and sustain.

Desires for wealth, for nobility, for longevity—these are common to every human heart. Yet the cycles of rain and sunshine, of warmth and cold, remain unfathomable in the heavens’ timing. How much more so the misfortunes of flood and drought, the unpredictability of famine, or the sudden onset of plague and pestilence? When even a single being finds no peace, We hold Ourself personally accountable.

Deeply mindful of all within the embrace of Heaven and Earth, of the numinous spirits both hidden and manifest—some clinging to grass and trees without refuge, others howling to the moon and wind without shelter—We extend Our concern even to the multitudes of flying, walking, and creeping creatures, to the humble beings born of womb, egg, moisture, or transformation, long sunk in suffering with no means of deliverance.

Reverently praying for blessings and abundant fortune, we humbly beseech that His Imperial Majesty’s benevolence equal Heaven and Earth, his sagely years match the sun and moon in radiance. May his sacred longevity endure like mountains and rivers, as eternal as the cosmos. May auspicious signs repeatedly manifest, and the myriad treasures ever flourish. May the common folk joyfully sing while tilling the soil, and foreign lands hasten to present tribute. My heart brims with fervent devotion, awaiting the boundless grace to come.

With utmost reverence, I present this for the thousand autumns to come.

Your humble servant, holding office at the sacred shrine, has been graced by the radiance of the vermilion steps. My person ascends the turtle’s summit, where I gaze reverently toward the Azure Palace. On this propitious morning, as stars over the islets manifest their auspices, all within the realm prostrate themselves in joyful homage.

On this day of the present month, I devoutly gather the Daoist assembly to this very palace, where we follow the prescribed rites to inaugurate the Daoist arena. We proclaim our humble devotion and recite the profound scriptures. At dawn, we establish the Pure Offering to the True Lord, extol the Star Lamps of the Northern Dipper, and perform the secret scriptures. Upon the completion of these virtuous deeds, we hold a jiao offering to express gratitude.

Reverently praying for abundant blessings, we humbly beseech that His Highness the Crown Prince, inheriting the ancestral virtue, succeed to the eternal foundation. May he brilliantly assist the sagely model and enjoy a longevity of a thousand autumns. May he further strengthen the great root and personally embody utmost benevolence. May the Chinese and barbarians alike unite in harmony, and gods and men rejoice in his rule.

My heart brims with fervent devotion, awaiting the boundless grace to come. With utmost reverence, I present this.

On this auspicious dawn at the Golden Palace,

Your faithful servant, an official, prostrates himself. Since ancient times, the immortal’s name has been inscribed upon the lofty steps for his achievements in the Eastern Sea. His divine traces in the southern lands have manifested great blessings in this flourishing age. Loyal in upholding the altars of state, he is called upright and enlightened; benevolent toward all living beings, he brings them peace, ease, wealth, and longevity. Now, as auspicious omens descend from the Dipper’s abode, we specially offer praise and celebration in the Jade Palace.

With reverence, on the seventeenth day of the ninth month, we gather the Daoist assembly at this palace and follow the prescribed rites to inaugurate the Daoist arena. We convey our sincere devotion, kindle the Star Lamps, and extol the original vows. We specially establish the Pure Offering, transforming ordinary tributes into sacred rites. Invoking the True Compassion, we reverently pray for abundant fortune.

We humbly beseech that His Imperial Majesty’s longevity equal the mountains, his reign proclaimed to the four barbarians. May his virtue blanket Heaven and Earth, his dominion extend over ten thousand lands. May auspicious charts and propitious records flow unceasingly from the historians’ brushes. May surplus grain and lingering harvests repeatedly fulfill the farmers’ hopes. May court and countryside alike rejoice, and gods and men achieve harmony.

My heart brims with awe and devotion, awaiting the boundless grace to come. With utmost reverence, I present this.

On this auspicious dawn at the Jade Palace.

The faithful official [Name], with utmost reverence, makes a great vow within the Five Illuminations Palace, multiplying his form to uphold the Daoist teachings. At the Dragon’s Head of Three Mountains, he expounds the wondrous Dao, manifesting traces to achieve success. He illuminates divine beneficence to aid the myriad ages, assisting the state and protecting the people in this present day.

Reflecting with awe upon the imperial command, I reverently serve the numinous perfected. Moved by the sagely governance and transformative grace of the August Thearch, I bear the benevolent blessings of the transcendent immortals. With no means to repay such kindness, I turn my thoughts to cultivation and reverence. Now, on this propitious occasion of the Middle Prime Festival of the Earth Official, and the auspicious dawn of the August Graceful Perfected Lord, I humbly lay bare my sincerest devotion, offering it up to the exalted and luminous.

With deepest respect, I ascend the first Golden Roc, gazing reverently toward the Jade Palace of the Nine Heavens. I extend this celebration in humble gratitude, a small repayment for boundless favor. On this day, I devoutly gather the Daoist clergy, following the rituals to perform the rites. Spreading forth my sincere intent, I open the sacred precinct. I kindle and offer the Seven Luminaries’ star lamps, chanting the numinous scriptures of the original vows. Again, I establish the Pure Offering, presenting ordinary tributes as sacred rites. I manifest my thanks for Heaven’s grace, reverently praying for abundant fortune.

May the sagely longevity equal the enduring firmament, and the imperial enterprise be as steadfast as the mountains. May the Three Lights remain whole and the seasons harmonious, the Five Grains ripen and the people flourish. May the temple courtyards be solemn and serene, bringing peace and well-being to all beings. May the faithful who take refuge all rely upon the aid and protection of the cloud-like heavens.

My heart brims with awe and devotion, awaiting the boundless grace to come. With utmost reverence, I present this.

The Divine Consort of Jingguo on this Auspicious Dawn,

Your humble servant [Name], prostrate in reverence, gazes toward Ao Peak, honored by the sacred commendation of steadfast response. Adorned in ceremonial robes, she magnifies the virtue of bestowing life, in harmony above with the Golden Towers and below with the Petal Palaces.

Now, as the celestial pivot turns in its propitious cycle and this joyous birthday aligns with felicitous omens, I offer my exultant congratulations and humble gratitude for her august benevolence. With utmost devotion, on the thirteenth day of the first month, I gather the Daoist assembly to perform the rites in accordance with the sacred canons. I establish a grand Offering dedicated to the Divine Consort, chanting the numinous scriptures of the Petal Canon. Extending reverence to all the celestial palaces, I present these modest tributes, circling the ritual altar in hope of her boundless grace.

May the imperial enterprise stand firm, as unshakable as bedrock. May the imperial lineage flourish and prosper, extending its branches through ten thousand generations. May transformative governance bring moral beauty, and the people’s songs resound like the harmonious *fuyi*. May the qi flow in harmony with the seasons, and the land present auspicious omens of jade-like lingzhi. Overwhelmed with gratitude, I pray for eternal peace and prosperity.

My heart brims with awe and devotion beyond measure. With utmost reverence, I present this.

On the Auspicious Dawn of the Divine Consort of State-Protection,
this humble official [Name] prostrates himself, reflecting thus:

Her virtue is marked by grace, gentleness, reverence, and tranquility, perfectly harmonizing with the Jade Realm. Her pure and refined demeanor bestows life, and she has long been ranked among the celestial ranks. Flowing with elegance, she embodies serene majesty.

Now, on this propitious dawn of her birth, I humbly offer my modest sincerity in celebration. On the seventeenth day of the seventh month, I reverently gather the Daoist clergy to uphold the rites and perform a grand Offering dedicated to the Divine Consort, chanting the numinous scriptures of the Petal Canon. Extending reverence to all the celestial palaces, I present these modest tributes, circling the ritual altar in hope of her boundless grace.

May the imperial longevity endure, bestowing the celestial patterns for ten thousand years. May sagely governance bring harmony, uniting all under heaven in shared culture and virtue. May blessings extend to the imperial lineage, and her power embrace both spirits and mortals. May yin and yang harmonize like the balanced flame of the jade candle, and the elderly enjoy the joys of Huaxu.

My heart brims with awe and devotion beyond measure. With utmost reverence, I present this.

**Ritual Protocol for Sacrificial Offerings**
*Document No. 52, Verified by the Ministry of Rites at the Temporary Court*

1. **Sacrificial Offerings**: Two altars in total.
   - Each altar includes: one sheep and one pig, three kinds of fruit, one bolt of silk, and white ritual silk as prescribed by protocol.
   - The above offerings shall be procured with official funds, exempt from confiscation or penalty.

2. **Ritual Protocol**:
   - Six officiants shall be appointed.
   - The *Zanyin* (usher) shall guide the presenting official to the washing station, where the *Zan* (assistant) shall instruct the donning of the *zhi* (ritual tablet).
   - After washing, the *Zan* shall announce the departure.
   - The *Zanyin* shall lead the official to the position, whereupon music begins. The *Zan* shall instruct four bows, and the music ceases.
   - The *Zan* shall announce the presentation of silk, followed by the initial libation.
   - The substitute shall approach the divine position, and the *Zan* shall instruct the donning of the *zhi*.
   - The officiants shall present the silk to the presenting official, followed by the offering of the cup. The *zhi* shall then be removed.
   - The *Zan* shall instruct the substitute to proceed to the prayer-reading position and kneel. After the prayer is read, the *Zan* shall instruct prostration, rising, and standing.
   - The *Zan* shall announce the secondary libation, after which the officiants shall complete the offering.
   - The *Zan* shall instruct four bows, followed by the burning of the prayer and silk. The substitute shall proceed to the burning site, and the ritual shall conclude.

3. **Sacrificial Schedule**: Conducted biannually in spring and autumn, on a chosen day of the second month.

4. **Sacrificial Prayer**:
   In the year [Year], in the [Month] month, on the [Day] day of the lunar cycle, the Emperor dispatches [Name] to offer sacrifice to...

To the Radiant Perfected Lords of the Nine Heavens’ Golden Gates, who embody the Illuminated Dao and manifest virtue, the Great Immortals of boundless efficacy—those of the Pure Subtlety, Cavernous Mystery, and Empty Void—whose wondrous responsiveness, compassion, and grace shield the realm and shelter the people with vast benevolence:

To the Perfected Lords of the Nine Heavens’ Jade Gates, who proclaim transformation and uphold the teachings, the Exalted Immortals of far-reaching efficacy—those of lofty clarity, vast tranquility, and profound serenity—whose wondrous resonance, benevolence, and mercy assist the state and protect the people with boundless grace:

It is said:
These deities, entrusted with office in the Nine Heavens, manifest their numinous power in the southern lands. They spread their protection over the common folk, lend their wings to the state, and through the subtlety of the Dao and the profundity of virtue, their merits tower and their deeds shine forth. Thus, in accord with ritual propriety, they are honored with steadfast sacrifices each year. Now, at the mid-spring and mid-autumn seasons, we reverently present offerings of sacrificial animals and sweet wine. May they deign to partake.

Two altars are arranged.

Officials are appointed to conduct the rites.

chunks.original_text: 徐仙真录 经名：徐仙真录。 明方文照编。 五卷。 底本出处：《万历续道藏》。 徐仙真录序 天生英才，用之於当时，则能忠君保民，荣膺显爵。 殁则庙祀一方，而其阴功灵贶，犹能阐扬于后世者，实非偶然。 盖天将有意於斯世斯民，而使其至於是也。 不然何独异於人哉。 若徐二仙者，槩可见矣。 神，海州胸山人也。 出偃王之后。 其父温，五代时为吴名将，能建军功，累迁官至拜相，卒赠齐王，谧忠武。 五子皆受王封，曰知证，曰知夸者，即二仙也。 天福中，唐主受禅，封知证为江王，知夸为饶王，同镇金陵。 威德兼济，民庶ㄨ安。 率兵入闽，蛮寇迎降，境土宁静。

**The True Records of the Xu Immortals**

**Scripture Title:** *The True Records of the Xu Immortals*
Compiled by Fang Wenzhao of the Ming dynasty. Five juan in total.
Base text sourced from the *Wanli Continuation of the Daoist Canon*.

**Preface to *The True Records of the Xu Immortals***

When heaven endows a person with extraordinary talent and they apply it in their time, they may serve their lord with loyalty, protect the people, and attain illustrious rank and honor. Even after death, their temple is venerated in their homeland, and their hidden merits and numinous blessings continue to manifest in later generations—this is no mere coincidence. For heaven must have a purpose for this world and its people, guiding them to such an end. Otherwise, how could they be so unlike others? As for the two Xu Immortals, their case is plainly evident.

The Divine Immortals were natives of Xiong Mountain in Haizhou. They descended from the lineage of King Yan. Their father, Xu Wen, was a renowned general of Wu during the Five Dynasties period. Through his military achievements, he rose through the ranks, eventually being appointed as chancellor. Upon his death, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the Prince of Qi and granted the posthumous title *Zhongwu* ("Loyal and Martial"). All five of his sons received princely titles. Among them were Xu Zhizheng and Xu Zhikua—these were the two Immortals.

During the Tianfu era, the Tang sovereign received the abdication of the throne. Zhizheng was enfeoffed as the Prince of Jiang, and Zhikua as the Prince of Rao. Together, they governed Jinling, their virtue and authority jointly flourishing, bringing peace to the people. They led troops into Min, where the barbarian bandits surrendered, and the borders became tranquil.

chunks.original_text: 闽人归戴； 遂立生祠於鳌峰之北，设像以敬事焉。 神念其诚，一日，语闽人曰：我明年别汝辈、当默佑兹土。 果符前言，於是闽人敬事益虔。 而凡旱潦虫蝗之灾，水火寇盗之危，疾病婚葬之请，随祷随应，若响若答。 至若摛词挥翰，云汉昭回，耀人耳目。 自宋以来，累受封号。 逮至我朝永乐之间，以神有翊卫圣躬弗豫之功，聿新祠庙，御制碑刻，褒封有加，以昭神贶。 由此而观，则神生为忠臣，殁为明神，其功德有益於国家生民者。 如此，岂非天有意於斯世斯民，而使其至於是欤。 其祠官方文照，盖凡神之世系、行实、灵迹、华翰，与夫前代我朝褒封碑刻，恐岁久湮没失传，汇成一编，名曰真录。 闽藩总戎盂城孙公，忠义士也，窃尝观之，而有感焉，乃捐俸，命工绣梓，以博其传，命予序引。 予谓神聪明正直，其显迹着于今昔者，皆不出於隐僻怪，诞而至於惑世诬民之患，莫非忠君孝亲，仁民爱物之事，盖士君子之所当为也。 其近而耳闻目见者，固－不待是编而知，使遐方僻壤未及见闻者，幸获一览，其於为臣为子之道，修身慎行之方，亦足为一助云耳。 是为序。 正统八年，岁在癸亥秋七月吉日，福建闽县儒学训导王用盛序。 重刊徐仙真录题辞 徐仙真录者，洪恩灵济二真君之行实也。 内列图像，与夫前代封赠之由，及我太宗文皇帝勑建宫宇，御制碑文、为善阴骘之书所载赞颂、累受加封诰命，醮祭，褒扬词旨，列圣崇祀，赐衣仪典，并真君降笔所为古赋、记序、诗歌、签兆，翰藻云章，天机焕发，照耀古今。 其奉祠之官方文照等，汇而集之，丽为上下之编，凡若干卷，以纪真君斡运神化，福国裕民之功，默卫圣躬，阴翊皇度之德，灵应显异，莫不具载。 是书旧有刊本，年久，漫不可考，且无今日之全备。 编订校雠，缮写成恢，将谩枣以广其传。

The people of Min revered and followed them; thus, they established a shrine to the living deities north of Aofeng, installing statues to honor and serve them. Moved by their sincerity, the deities one day addressed the people of Min: "Next year, I shall depart from you all, but I will silently protect this land." True to their word, the people of Min grew even more devout in their reverence. Whenever disasters struck—droughts, floods, locust plagues, or perils like fires, banditry, and theft—whenever illness, marriages, or funerals required prayers, their supplications were answered as swiftly as an echo. Their literary compositions and calligraphy shone like the radiant Milky Way, dazzling the eyes and ears.

Since the Song dynasty, the deities have received numerous honorific titles. By the Yongle era of our present dynasty, in recognition of their merit in safeguarding the sacred person of the Emperor during his indisposition, their temple was newly renovated. An imperial stele was commissioned, and their posthumous honors were further augmented to manifest the deities' benevolence. From this, we may observe that in life, they were loyal ministers, and in death, enlightened deities—such was the magnitude of their virtue and merit, benefiting both the state and the people. Could this not be the intent of Heaven for this world and its people, that they should attain such a state?

The temple official Fang Wenzhao compiled a record encompassing the deities' lineage, deeds, miraculous manifestations, literary works, and the imperial honors and steles bestowed upon them by previous dynasties and our present court, fearing that with the passage of time, these might fade into obscurity. He titled it *The True Record*. Sun Mengcheng, the military commander of Min and a man of loyalty and righteousness, having read it, was deeply moved. He donated his salary to commission artisans to carve and print the work, ensuring its wider dissemination, and tasked me with writing a preface.

I say: the deities were wise, upright, and just. Their wondrous deeds, both past and present, never strayed into obscurity, eccentricity, or deceit—never did they mislead the world or deceive the people. All their actions were those of loyalty to the sovereign, filial piety to parents, benevolence toward the people, and care for all things—precisely what a scholar-official ought to do. Those who have witnessed or heard of these deeds firsthand need not rely on this compilation to know them. Yet for those in distant and remote regions who have not yet learned of them, this work may serve as a fortunate guide, offering aid in the Way of being a loyal minister and filial child, and in the methods of cultivating oneself and conducting affairs with caution.

Thus, this preface.

Written on an auspicious day in the seventh month of autumn, the eighth year of the Zhengtong era (1443), by Wang Yongsheng, Instructor of the Confucian School of Min County, Fujian.

**Preface to the Reprinted *True Record of the Xu Immortals***

*The True Record of the Xu Immortals* chronicles the deeds of the Two Perfected Lords of Vast Grace and Numinous Aid. Within its pages are portraits, the origins of their imperial honors from previous dynasties, and the edicts of our Taizong Wen Emperor commanding the construction of their palace-temple, along with his imperial stele inscriptions. It includes the laudatory verses from *The Book of Hidden Virtue for Doing Good*, the successive imperial decrees of enfeoffment, the rituals of sacrificial offerings, the eulogies of praise, the veneration of successive sages, the bestowal of ceremonial robes, and the literary works composed by the Perfected Lords through spirit-writing—ancient rhapsodies, records, prefaces, poems, divination slips, and resplendent calligraphy—all radiant with celestial brilliance, illuminating past and present.

The temple officials, including Fang Wenzhao, compiled and assembled these materials into two volumes, totaling several scrolls, to record the Perfected Lords' divine transformations in governing the cosmos, their merits in enriching the state and benefiting the people, their silent protection of the sacred person, their unseen support of imperial authority, and their numinous responses and wondrous manifestations—all meticulously documented.

In the second year of the Kaiyun reign of the Jin (945), he led troops into Min, passing through Jin’ao Peak where he stationed his forces to suppress bandits. Upon attaining immortality, his hidden and manifest powers brought life to the people. A local man, Fang Jue, first established a shrine on Zhiyu Island—now called the Ancestral Temple. Within these texts are steles, biographies, postscripts, prefaces, petitions, eulogies, memorials, as well as the *Rhapsody on Jin’ao Peak* and *In Praise of the Mural Image*—each composition unique, their marvels ever unfolding. The elder then addressed me, saying: 'The deity’s divine manifestations are vivid in the people’s sight, and his hidden merits are fully recorded in these books. Though the books exist, they lack a preface. I humbly request a few words from you.' Unable to refuse, I replied: The deity lived in his era as a man of unparalleled brilliance. Devoted to the study of the Mysterious Dao, he and his kin ascended together to the immortal register, leaving their traces on Jin’ao Peak. The mountain’s vital qi converged in him, and his glory, honored with temple offerings, bestowed blessings upon the region. Why, then, was he long concealed? The fortunes of a land wax and wane, and the workings of destiny alternate between concealment and revelation. The deity foresaw the omens, and though his virtue briefly languished, he vented it through writing—his ethereal brush startling the world, its radiance dazzling the multitude. At times, his numinous power manifested, and prayers were answered as swiftly as an echo. As his cultivated deeds were transmitted and compiled, the records spread through the world, nurturing the vital qi of all beings for over four hundred years.

Now, under the sacred dynasty’s unification, virtue overflows between Hua and Yi. Moved by the deity’s spirit, the court bestowed the title of *Perfected Lord of Numinous Aid*, extolling his hidden virtue and greatly amplifying his divine might. He assists the state and shelters the people, repeatedly bestowing auspicious signs, revered throughout the Four Seas. Thus, his virtue is recorded, his honors grandly proclaimed. With spring and autumn sacrifices, his merits are inscribed on steles, enduring for eternity. At such a propitious juncture, the harmony between deity and humanity is no mere coincidence."

Thus, this preface is written.

**Volume One of the *True Record of Master Xu***
**The Lineage of the Xu Immortals**

Xu Wen, styled Dunmei, was a native of Qushan in Haizhou. He had five sons: Xu Zhixun, Xu Zhijian, Xu Zhixun, Xu Zhizheng, and Xu Zhie. He also had an adopted son, Xu Zhigao. Initially serving under Yang Xingmi, Wen rose to the rank of Right Guard Commander through merit and began participating in military councils. In the sixth year of the Tianyou reign (909), the Lord of Wu appointed him Prefect of Shengzhou, where he commanded the naval forces at Jinling. In the twelfth year (915), he was promoted to Military Commissioner of Runzhou, Defender-in-Chief of the Zhenhai Army, and Grand Councilor. In the twelfth month of winter, he was enfeoffed as Duke of Qi and concurrently appointed Pacification Commissioner of the Two Zhe. Upon assuming his post in Runzhou, he designated Sheng, Run, Xuan, Chang, Huang, and Chi as the domains of the State of Qi, establishing the Grand Military Prefecture in Shengzhou. In the sixteenth year (919), he was appointed Grand Chancellor and Commander-in-Chief of All Military Affairs. In the fourth year of the Tongguang reign (926), he was posthumously honored as Grand Chancellor. Wen’s four generations of ancestors were enshrined in Jinling. He died in the second year of the Tiancheng reign (927), and the Lord of Wu posthumously conferred upon him the title of King of Qi, with the posthumous name *Zhongwu*. He is now revered as the *Perfected Lord of Loyalty and Brilliance, Supporter of the Qi King*.

Xu Zhigao, styled Zhenglun, later restored his surname to Li and changed his name to Li Sheng. A native of Xuzhou, he was orphaned young and drifted to Haozhou, where Yang Xingmi obtained him as a gift. Wen, a man of warmth and cunning, served as Wu’s Naval Commander, stationing troops in Jinling. Later, for his merits, he was appointed Prefect of Shengzhou. In the fifteenth year of the Tianyou reign (918), Wu appointed him Deputy Military Commissioner and Assistant Administrator, ordering him to resume his title as King of Haidong. In the sixteenth year (919), he was made Left Chief Minister, Participant in Government Affairs, and concurrently Commander of All Military Affairs. In the fourth year of the Tiancheng reign (929), the Lord of Wu appointed Zhigao Grand Councilor. In the second year of the Changxing reign (931), the Lord of Wu stationed Zhigao in Jinling, reappointing him as Military Commissioner of Zhenhai and Ningguo, where he governed Jinling and oversaw all court affairs. In the third year (932), he expanded Jinling’s walls. In the fourth year (933), he constructed palaces in Jinling. In the second year of the Qingtai reign (935), the Lord of Wu appointed Zhigao Grand Marshal, enfeoffed him as King of Qi, and accorded him exceptional rites. In the second year of the Tianfu reign (937), Zhigao established the State of Qi in Jinling. In autumn, Wu’s Crown Prince Lian married Zhigao’s daughter as his consort. Thereupon, he established the Imperial Ancestral Temple and the Altar of Soil and Grain, renaming Jinling as Jiangning Prefecture. In the eighth month of autumn, the Lord of Wu, Pu, presented the abdication decree to King of Qi Zhigao, who then restored his surname to Li, changed his name to Sheng, and honored Xu Wen as his adoptive ancestor. All of Xu’s sons were enfeoffed as kings, and his daughters as commandery and county ladies. He is now revered as the *Tang King of this palace*.

He is now revered as Marshal Zha, the Eternal Guardian of Lingji Palace.

Bian Gao, in the eighth year of the Tianfu reign (943), was appointed by the Lord of Tang as Gentleman for Court Audiences and sent to crush the rebel Zhang Yuxian in Qianzhou, whom he captured and brought back. In the ninth year (944), Gao was appointed Prefect of Xinzhou. In autumn, when great turmoil erupted in Chu, Tang dispatched troops to attack, breaking through Tanzhou. Gao was then appointed Military Commissioner of Hunan, and is now revered as Marshal Bian, the Martial Guardian of Lingji Palace.

Wei Cen, in the ninth year of the Tianfu reign (944), was appointed by the Lord of Tang as Vice Director of the Bureau of Military Affairs. In the twelfth year (947), Cen was sent to pacify Zhang and Quan prefectures, later reassigned as Military Supervisor. He was subsequently appointed Gentleman Attendant to the Crown Prince, and is now revered as Marshal Wei, Left Supervisor of the Military Commission of Lingji Palace.

Zhao Zhong, styled Wende, was initially appointed by the Lord of Tang as Prefect of Chizhou, later recalled and entrusted with the governorship of Xuanzhou. He is now revered as Marshal Zhao, Right Supervisor of the Capital Armies of Lingji Palace.

Diao Yanneng, in the seventh year of the Tianfu reign (942), was appointed by the Lord of Tang as Pacification Commissioner, and is now revered as Marshal Diao, Vanguard Commander of the Capital Armies of Lingji Palace.

chunks.original_text: 宋乾道二年丙戌，方询、方感、方仲，上其事於州牧，号曰护境感应。 熙宁三年庚戌，林怀贤等，上其事於光禄卿程师孟保奏。 八年乙卯，刘彝、周汝砺复具状以闻。 绍定元年戊子，安抚使薛弼，保奏於朝。 端平元年甲午，左藏周说、潮守周燧，具其事於执政李宗勉保奏。 端平三年丙申，宋理宗封： 九天金阙明道达德大仙显灵溥济真人，江王。 九天玉阙宣化扶教上仙昭灵博济真人，饶王。 父，齐王，忠武真人。 母田氏，仁寿仙妃。 配许氏，顺助仙惠仙妃。 陶氏，善助慈懿仙妃。 嘉熙元年，勑庙额日灵济宫。 大明永乐十四年丙申，郎中王羽、尚书方宾奏神绩於朝。 次年丁酉，太宗文皇帝加封： 金阙曰清微洞玄冲虚妙感慈惠洪恩真人。 玉阙日高明弘静冲湛妙应仁惠洪恩真人。 父，翊亮真人。 母，淑善仙妃。 许氏，贞应仙妃。 陶氏，恭静仙妃。 永乐十六年戊戌加封： 金阙护国庇民洪恩真君。 玉阙辅国佑民洪恩真君。 父，翊亮真君。 加庙额曰洪恩灵济宫。 宣德十年乙卯，皇上登宝位加封： 金阙崇福洪恩真君。 玉阙降福洪恩真君。 鳌峰始祠 自晋开运二年乙巳，真君率师入闽驻兵除寇，乡人立祠於鳌峰。 宋太平兴国八年癸未，更立祖庙，旧址尚存，即今佛舍前是也。 至大明永乐甲辰，共四百七十九年。 洪恩灵济祖庙 宋太平兴国八年癸未，檀越方珏始立祖庙，以石为室，诸祠皆本於此，岁时祀礼，方氏主之。 至正七年丁亥，方壮猷、方逢午、方嗣翕重建，复立祖庙碑。 至永乐三年乙酉，方文照等募缘重建，更坐向子午。 至大明永乐甲辰，共四百四十二年。 演溪社坛 宋祥符元年戊申，立庙於演溪，分祖庙香火而奉祠焉。 至政和七年丁酉，迁于洪恩灵济宫，遂废其地，即今称曰社坛。 洪恩灵济宫 宋政和七年丁酉，因废演溪，迁立宫於此地，坐向甲庚。 乡之父老，每岁奉神，朝于祖庙，牲醴祀事，示不忘本。 至正十三年癸巳，沈建翁等重建立碑。 后方涣、方汶等，增广明堂，更立门表。 大明永乐八年庚寅，方文照等，募缘重建。 永乐十五年丁酉，勑内臣同方面正官，率领军夫，增广地基，从新盖造，御制碑文。 至永乐甲辰，共三百九年。 旗龙仙祠 宋宣和七年乙巳，初立坛墠。 后祈雨有应，创祠，因号祈雨王。 淳熙十一年甲辰，乡人郭希圣重建。 元贞元年乙未，张丰等重修。

In the second year of the Qiandao reign of the Song (1166), Fang Xun, Fang Gan, and Fang Zhong reported these matters to the Prefect, who named it "Divine Response Protecting the Realm." In the third year of the Xining reign (1070), Lin Huaixian and others presented the case to Cheng Shimeng, Minister of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices, who memorialized the throne. In the eighth year (1075), Liu Yi and Zhou Ruli again submitted a detailed report. In the first year of the Shaoding reign (1228), Pacification Commissioner Xue Bi memorialized the court. To the Golden Portal: "Perfected One of the Nine Heavens, Illuminating the Dao, Attaining Virtue, Great Immortal, Manifestly Numinous, Universally Beneficent" (Jiang, King of the River).
To the Jade Portal: "Perfected One of the Nine Heavens, Proclaiming Transformation, Upholding the Teachings, Supreme Immortal, Radiantly Numinous, Vastly Beneficent" (Rao, King of Rao).

In the fourteenth year of the Yongle reign of the Great Ming (1416), Langzhong Wang Yu and Minister Fang Bin memorialized the throne regarding the deities’ merits. In the following year (1417), Emperor Taizong of the Ming bestowed further titles:

To the Jade Portal: "Perfected One of Lofty Clarity, Vast and Serene, Profoundly Still, Wondrously Responsive, Benevolent and Gracious."

To the Jade Portal: "Perfected Lord of Vast Grace, Assisting the State and Aiding the People."

In the tenth year of the Xuande reign (1435), upon the emperor’s ascension, further titles were bestowed:
To the Golden Portal: "Perfected Lord of Vast Grace and Exalted Blessings."
To the Jade Portal: "Perfected Lord of Vast Grace and Descending Blessings."

*The Founding of the Ao Peak Shrine*
In the second year of the Kaiyun reign of the Jin (945), the Perfected Lords led their troops into Min, stationing forces to suppress bandits. The villagers established a shrine at Ao Peak. In the eighth year of the Taiping Xingguo reign of the Song (983), an ancestral temple was rebuilt, with the old site still extant—now the location before the Buddhist hall. By the Jiachen year of the Yongle reign of the Great Ming (1424), 479 years had passed.

*The Hong’en Lingji Ancestral Temple*
In the eighth year of the Taiping Xingguo reign of the Song (983), lay devotee Fang Jue first established the ancestral temple, constructing it of stone. All branch temples trace their origins here, with the Fang clan presiding over seasonal sacrifices. In the seventh year of the Zhizheng reign (1347), Fang Zhuangyou, Fang Fengwu, and Fang Sixi rebuilt it and erected an ancestral temple stele. In the third year of the Yongle reign (1405), Fang Wenzhao and others raised funds to rebuild it, altering its orientation to due north-south. By the Jiachen year of the Yongle reign of the Great Ming (1424), 442 years had passed.

*The Yanxi Community Altar*
In the first year of the Xiangfu reign of the Song (1008), a temple was established at Yanxi, receiving incense from the ancestral temple for worship. In the seventh year of the Zhenghe reign (1117), it was relocated to Hong’en Lingji Palace, and the original site was abandoned—now known as the Community Altar.

*The Hong’en Lingji Palace*
In the seventh year of the Zhenghe reign of the Song (1117), due to the abandonment of Yanxi, the palace was relocated to this site, oriented toward the northeast-southwest. Each year, the village elders led the people to pay homage at the ancestral temple, offering sacrifices of animals and wine to demonstrate their remembrance of origins. In the thirteenth year of the Zhizheng reign (1353), Shen Jianweng and others rebuilt it and erected a stele. Later, Fang Huan, Fang Wen, and others expanded the main hall and erected new gate structures.

In the eighth year of the Yongle reign of the Great Ming (1410), Fang Wenzhao and others raised funds to rebuild it. In the fifteenth year (1417), by imperial decree, eunuchs and local officials led military laborers to expand the foundation and reconstruct the palace, with an imperial inscription for the stele. By the Jiachen year of the Yongle reign (1424), 309 years had passed.

*The Qilong Immortal Shrine*
In the seventh year of the Xuanhe reign of the Song (1125), an altar was first established. Later, prayers for rain were answered, and a shrine was built, hence the name "Praying-for-Rain King." In the eleventh year of the Chunxi reign (1184), villager Guo Xisheng rebuilt it. In the first year of the Yuanzhen reign (1295), Zhang Feng and others renovated it.

chunks.original_text: 至大明永乐甲辰，共三百年。 香火源流 灵济香火，遍於一方。 当时人物繁盛，随处立庙，如玉水清江桂宫，岳山玉坂，富山旗龙，新安江尾石舍。 蓬山青布之西，南北至於白鹿，合山慈氏福藏，护法迦蓝，殿庙虽异，香火皆本於祖宫，其实洪恩真君之一源也。 各祠将帅不同，乃立庙时，随真君所遣。 徐仙出相传 灵济宫祖祠，廊废东西，图像屹然。 恒童幼间，闻诸先生言曰：此乃徐二仙灵庙食之事迹，逐节传文，以纪其实，系诗于后，以赞其德。 初自好善持经，以至阴功济人，立庙芝屿，延蔓香火，节节有序。 使登斯堂，而一览数百年之往事如在。 今日来者，莫不钦叹而加敬畏焉。
chunks.translated_text:
By the Jiachen year of the Yongle reign of the Great Ming (1424), 300 years had passed.

**Origins of the Incense Flame**
The incense flame of Lingji spread throughout the region. In those days, with the flourishing of people and places, temples were established everywhere—such as the Jade Water and Clear River Osmanthus Palace, Yue Mountain and Jade Slope, Fu Mountain and Qilong, and the Stone Abode at the end of Xin’an River. To the west of Peng Mountain and Qingbu, from north to south as far as White Deer, encompassing the Cishi (Maitreya) Blessing Treasury of Heshan, the Dharma-Protecting *Kalyāṇa*-Spirits—though their halls and temples differed, their incense flames all traced back to the ancestral palace, for in truth they sprang from the same source: the Vast Grace True Lord.

The generals and marshals of each shrine varied, having been dispatched by the True Lord at the time of each temple’s founding.

**The Legend of Immortal Xu**
In the ancestral shrine of Lingji Palace, though the eastern and western corridors had fallen into ruin, the murals stood firm. In my youth, I often heard scholars say: these depict the deeds of the two Xu Immortals, whose temple offerings were established. The events are recorded in sequence, their truth preserved, and poems appended to praise their virtue.

From their early devotion to goodness and scripture-holding to their hidden merits in aiding others, from the founding of the Zhiyu Temple to the spreading of incense flames, each step followed in order. Entering this hall, one gazes upon centuries of bygone affairs as if they were present. Today, all who come cannot but revere and stand in awe.

chunks.original_text: 历年既久，图像朽昧，恒虑湮没，是以备录於书，垂示无穷。 复以大明永乐，彰灵显应，敬天勤民，以继其后。 此亦神之灵德，复兴於永乐年。 林丘散人黄恒顿首谨书。 好善修行 二仙乃徐偃王后，南唐徐温之子，海州朐山人也。 自幼好善，笃志侑行。 每遇贫窘，乐而施与。 平时服御，不尚华侈。 一切游玩，不贵珍奇。 宁甘淡泊，每旦常素食。 自是功行日增，成登道岸。 诗曰：良因善果世难寻，谁识修行乐道心。 丹火烧空堪爱处，昭彰灵贶古如今。 持经拜斗 自旦常素食，持念《玉皇经》、宝号、《北斗延生经》。 玄科秘典，无不周遍。 每夜斋戒沐浴，设香案。 惟与弟二人，告天拜斗。 期珍兵革，以安生民。 虽国政繁剧，不移志愿，恒勤经向道，久而愈笃焉。 诗曰：向道谁知日日勤，持经拜斗积功勋。 修成行满超三界，仙籍题名万古存。 封王镇国 唐主授禅晋天福二年丁酉，卦弟知证为江王，知谔为饶王，镇守金陵，抚辑流亡，控扼二十余州。 民征就宽，军给以铙。 林蛮洞蜓，守条死要。
chunks.translated_text:
As the years passed, the murals faded and dimmed, ever feared to be lost to oblivion. Thus, I have recorded them in full within this book, to be passed down for endless generations.

Moreover, in the reign of the Great Ming’s Yongle Emperor, their numinous efficacy and manifest responses shone forth—revering Heaven and diligently serving the people—to carry on their legacy. This, too, is the Immortals’ divine power, revived in the Yongle era.

Respectfully inscribed by Huang Heng, the Hermit of Linqiu, with bowed head.

**Devotion to Goodness and Cultivation of Conduct**
The Two Immortals were descendants of King Yan of Xu, sons of Xu Wen of the Southern Tang, and natives of Qushan in Haizhou. From youth, they cherished goodness and steadfastly pursued virtuous conduct. Whenever they encountered the poor and distressed, they gladly gave alms. In daily life, they disdained extravagance, valuing neither rare treasures nor frivolous amusements. Content with simplicity, they often ate plain meals at dawn. Thus, their merit and practice grew daily, leading them to ascend the Dao’s shore.

*Poem:*
Good causes and fruits are rare in the world,
Who knows the joy of cultivating the heart for the Dao?
The cinnabar fire burns the sky in a lovable place,
Their manifest blessings endure from ancient times to now.

**Holding Scriptures and Worshipping the Dipper**
At dawn, they ate plain meals and recited the *Jade Emperor Sutra*, sacred invocations, and the *Northern Dipper Longevity Sutra*. Esoteric rituals and secret texts were all thoroughly practiced. Each night, they fasted, bathed, and set up an incense altar. Only with their younger brother did they pray to Heaven and worship the Dipper, vowing to end warfare and pacify the people. Though state affairs were pressing, they never wavered in their resolve, ever diligently turning toward the Dao, their devotion deepening over time.

*Poem:*
Who knows their daily diligence in seeking the Dao?
Holding scriptures and worshipping the Dipper, they amassed merit.
When cultivation is complete and conduct perfected, they transcend the Three Realms,
Their names inscribed in the Immortals’ register for ten thousand ages.

**Enfeoffed as Kings to Pacify the Realm**
In the second year of Tianfu during the Later Jin’s abdication to the Tang (Dingyou, 757), the younger brother, Zhi Zheng, was enfeoffed as King of Jiang, and Zhi E as King of Rao. They were stationed in Jinling to soothe the displaced and defend over twenty prefectures. Taxes were lightened for the people, and provisions were ample for the troops. The barbarians of the forests and caves were subdued, holding fast to the essentials of governance and defense.

chunks.original_text: 稚耋嬉游，连手歌讴，江南之民，举赖以安焉。 诗曰：华萼联芳立世功，列分茅土受王封。 民安国泰讴歌动，守备金陵有尽忠。 父老迎师 晋开运之二年乙巳，闽王王氏阋墙之衅，兵革肆兴。 玉率查、边等骑万人入闽，驻节於峡江之南。 道经青布，乡之父老箪食壶浆，拥道以迎。 乡闽咸赖，民皆按堵。 秋毫无患，以遂其生焉。 诗曰：惟玉驻节峡江南，父老祗迎赖以安。 鸡犬不惊人按堵，秋毫无患吏民欢。 驻兵除寇 父老迎师怨於王曰：适有精兵数百，隐匿於鳌峰之巅，夸慢凶骄，将次为乱。 王师今下至闾井，朋邻深被扰害，弗能安生。 王遂悯之，乃引师南向，挫其峰，歼厥巨魁，不战而收，民皆安堵。 诗曰：鳌峰贼寇实堪惊，颠覆朋邻苦不宁。 一驻精兵清扫荡，万民生业得经营。 立祠祝寿 贼寇既平，师还。 父老攀慕顾恋，不忍释去。 遂剪茅为屋，於鳌峰龙湫之北，图像奉祀，晨香夕灯，以祝王寿。 王心恻然，与众盟曰：予明年当弃世，而寄於此矣。 祠之旧址，即今佛舍前是也。 诗曰：感佩深恩自有余，鳌峰潭北立生祠。 于时就与乡民誓，异日当为血食居。 授都水使 二王居世，笃志修行。 功成行满，道妙德玄。 上达天曹，名扬斗府，是年脱化於钩伍间。 以平时拜斗，兄弟联名，并得斗中都冰二使者。 出入天宫， 左执青节，右仗黄钺，侍立帝前，默佑下民。 诗曰：斗府延生秘不传，仙人道妙得真诠。 初为都水天门使，出入琼宫侍帝前。 灵宝说经 侑真得道诣五明宫中，参灵宝天尊，长跪而进言：夙生庆幸，得预天下。 下观欲界，多作恶业，全无惭愧，不知解悟，作何因缘，何以救度，愿垂怜悯。 天尊遂说经偈：能自修持，常居吉庆焉。 诗曰：玄门立教自垂科，亲授玄文得不讹。 惟有二仙归妙道，五明宫裹听经多。 黄庭秘诀 惟王初生尘士，授封王爵，不以位尊贵荣而自居，惟乐道穷经，清居守淡，虽功行圆满，名登仙籍。 而黄庭先生得其秘诀，久仰慕之。 晋开运间，故诣黄庭道士前，授长生秘诀《道德仙经》。 诗曰：黄庭道士意如何，秘诀长生世不过。 参到诸真栖隐处，许多经教与玄科。 参定光佛 二王自归仙道，大阐虚玄之秘，具其自然之妙，上佐斗真，下利群品。 后参释氏定光圆应普通慈济大师菩萨，直入真如之境。 契合神机，灵台内郎惠力，愈彰真空妙有之理，无不自得。 诗曰：古佛坛前入定还，真仙皈仰扣禅关。 了心见性空中有，玄释由来总一般。 符药济人 后周显得二年乙卯，王始降笔判符药以济人。 声闻达于四方，阴骘留人耳目。 敬之爱之，不啻父母，而赖保障，自是求神问事，无不感恁。 治病更苏，沉痾顿解。 神德愈彰，而人心皈仰矣。 诗曰：显德灵符散世间，仙方妙济几多般。 无求不应真神效，老者康庄病者安。 反风灭火 显德问乡人不谨，致回禄之灾。 初发一星，因风而炽。 炎炎猛烈，焚荡闾舍。 高梁大厦，顷刻皆除，尚延蔓不止。 民皆失色而无措，呼告二王，祈求救护。 遂鼓反风一吹，火烬皆灭，民咸感德。 诗曰：炎炎烈火燎人家，大厦高梁一旦赊。 神鼓反风吹灭火，民安居止案生涯。 沧峡救船 溪河通舟楫，闽川最为险峻，沧峡之水为尤难。 石濑巉岩，当流曲折，舟人多被阻坏。
chunks.translated_text:
Young and old alike frolicked and played, hand in hand singing songs of joy—thus the people of Jiangnan all found peace and stability.

*Poem:*
Fragrant blossoms stand united in meritorious deeds,
Enfeoffed with lands and titles as kings they received.
The land at peace, the people prosperous, songs resound,
Guarding Jinling with loyalty, their devotion profound.

**Elders Welcoming the Master**
In the second year of Kaiyun during the Later Jin (Yisi, 945), internal strife erupted within the Min kingdom under King Wang. Warfare raged unchecked. Yu led Generals Zha, Bian, and ten thousand cavalry into Min, stationing troops south of the Xiajiang. As they passed through Qingbu, the village elders offered baskets of food and jars of drink, lining the road to welcome them. The people of both Xiang and Min found refuge, living undisturbed in their homes. Not a hair was harmed, and all were able to live in peace.

*Poem:*
Yu stationed his troops south of Xiajiang’s gorge,
Elders welcomed him with reverence, their safety restored.
No fowl nor hound was startled, all remained secure,
Without harm, officials and people rejoiced as one.

**Stationing Troops to Eliminate Bandits**
The elders, having welcomed the master, voiced their grievances to the king: "Recently, several hundred elite soldiers have concealed themselves atop Aofeng Peak, acting with arrogance and violence, on the verge of causing chaos. Now that Your Majesty’s forces have arrived among the villages, neighboring communities suffer deeply from their disturbances and cannot live in peace." Moved by their plight, the king led his troops southward, subdued the peak, and annihilated the ringleaders without battle. The people all returned to their homes in peace.

*Poem:*
Bandits atop Aofeng Peak struck fear profound,
Neighboring lands suffered, no peace could be found.
With a single deployment, the elite forces swept clean,
And ten thousand people resumed their livelihoods serene.

**Erecting a Shrine to Offer Longevity Prayers**
Once the bandits were pacified, the master returned. The elders, filled with admiration and reluctance to part, could not bear to let him go. They cut thatch to build a hut north of Aofeng’s Dragon Pool, where they enshrined his image, offering morning incense and evening lamps to pray for the king’s longevity. The king, his heart touched, swore to the people: "Next year, I shall depart this world and reside here." The site of that old shrine is now before the Buddhist abode.

*Poem:*
Grateful for boundless grace, their devotion ran deep,
North of Aofeng’s pool, a shrine they did keep.
There, they pledged to the villagers with solemn vow,
That one day, his spirit would dwell among them now.

**Appointed as Directors of the Celestial Waters**
The two kings lived in the world with unwavering devotion to cultivation. Their merits complete and conduct perfected, their Dao profound and virtue mysterious, their names ascended to the celestial courts and resounded in the Dipper’s palace. That year, they transcended in the constellation of Gouwu. Due to their lifelong worship of the Dipper, the brothers’ names were jointly inscribed as the two Directors of the Dipper’s Waters. They entered and exited the heavenly palaces, holding a green tally in the left hand and wielding a yellow axe in the right, standing in attendance before the Emperor to silently protect the people below.

*Poem:*
The Dipper’s palace guards its secrets well,
Yet immortals, through the Dao’s mysteries, their truths tell.
First as Directors of the Celestial Waters they rose,
Entering jade palaces, serving the Emperor’s repose.

**The Numinous Treasure Expounds the Scriptures**
Having attained the Dao, Youzhen journeyed to the Five Luminaries Palace to pay homage to the Numinous Treasure Heavenly Worthy. Kneeling, he addressed the deity: "By fortune from past lives, I have been blessed to be counted among the world’s beings. Gazing below at the Desire Realm, I see many commit evil deeds without shame or remorse, unaware of awakening. By what karmic conditions may they be saved? I beseech your compassion." The Heavenly Worthy then expounded the scriptural verses: "Those who cultivate themselves shall ever dwell in auspicious blessings."

*Poem:*
The Mystic Gate’s teachings from ancient times unfold,
Its sacred texts imparted, their truths untold.
Only these two immortals grasped the Dao’s profound way,
In the Five Luminaries Palace, scriptures they did sway.

**The Yellow Court’s Secret Teachings**
Though the kings were born into the mortal realm and enfeoffed with royal titles, they did not cling to the honor and glory of their rank. Instead, they delighted in the Dao, exhaustively studying the classics, dwelling in purity and embracing simplicity. Even after their merits were complete and their names inscribed in the immortals’ register, the Master of the Yellow Court, having long admired them, sought their secret teachings. During the Kaiyun era of the Later Jin, he visited the Yellow Court Daoist and received the *Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue* on the secrets of longevity.

*Poem:*
What was the Yellow Court Daoist’s intent?
The secret of longevity the world could not prevent.
Having reached the abode where the perfected dwell,
Many scriptures and mysteries to them did swell.

**Paying Homage to the Buddha of Steadfast Light**
After the two kings returned to the Dao, they greatly propagated the secrets of emptiness and mystery, fully realizing their natural wonders. Above, they aided the Dipper’s immortals; below, they benefited all beings. Later, they paid homage to the Buddha of Steadfast Light, the Bodhisattva of Universal Compassion and Salvation, directly entering the realm of Suchness. Their minds aligned with the divine mechanism, their inner wisdom’s power flourished, further illuminating the principle of true emptiness and wondrous being—all was naturally attained.

*Poem:*
Before the ancient Buddha’s altar, in meditation deep,
True immortals bowed in reverence, the Chan gate to seek.
Mind realized, nature seen—emptiness within being,
Daoist and Buddhist truths, in essence, are one and the same.

**Talismans and Medicines to Aid the People**
In the second year of Xiande during the Later Zhou (Yimao, 955), the king began to issue talismanic judgments and prescribe medicines to aid the people. His fame spread in all directions, and his hidden merits lingered in the ears and eyes of the people. They revered and loved him as if he were their parents, relying on his protection. From then on, those who sought divine assistance or inquired of affairs found their prayers answered without fail. The sick were healed, and chronic illnesses vanished. His divine virtue grew ever more manifest, and the people’s hearts turned toward him in devotion.

*Poem:*
In Xiande’s reign, talismans spread far and wide,
With wondrous remedies, countless lives they did guide.
No plea went unanswered, his power truly divine,
The aged walked in health, the ill in peace did shine.

**Reversing the Wind to Extinguish Fire**
During the Xiande era, the villagers’ carelessness led to the disaster of Zaihuo. A single spark ignited, fanned by the wind into a raging blaze. Fierce and scorching, it consumed homes and dwellings. Towering beams and grand halls vanished in an instant, yet the flames continued to spread unchecked. The people, pale with fear, were at a loss, crying out to the two kings and begging for salvation. The kings then summoned a reverse wind with a single gust, extinguishing the flames entirely. The people all felt the depth of their virtue.

*Poem:*
A raging fire consumed the homes with might,
Grand halls and lofty beams vanished in its light.
With a divine gust, the wind reversed its course,
The people lived in peace, their livelihoods secure.

**Rescuing Boats at Cang Gorge**
The rivers and streams allowed for boat travel, with Min’s waterways being the most treacherous. The waters of Cang Gorge were especially perilous. Jagged rocks and towering cliffs lined the winding currents, causing many boats to be wrecked and stranded.

In the first year of the *Kaibao* reign of the Song, *wuchen* (8th year of the sexagenary cycle), a merchant vessel laden with goods nearly capsized. The boatmen cried out to the two kings, praying for protection. Suddenly, a faint yellow banner appeared amidst the clouds, and the boat sailed smoothly without peril.

*Poem:*
The Min’s waters, treacherous, bar the way,
Cang Gorge’s trials bring no small dismay.
Yet at their cries, a banner dimly shown,
The waves grew still, the currents gently flown.

**Dispelling Misfortune**
In the eighth year of the *Kaibao* reign, *dinghai* (24th year of the sexagenary cycle), during mid-spring, the seasonal *qi* was unbalanced. Villagers fell ill with pestilential sickness, entire households stricken in succession. Physicians’ treatments proved ineffective, and the affliction spread, some calling it the "toad miasma." The neighboring hamlets grew uneasy. They prayed at the shrine, where divine talismans and the wondrous remedies of the Celestial Physician were bestowed, bringing swift and miraculous cures. Thus were composed the *"Rhapsody on Dispelling Pestilence"* and the *"Incantation for Driving Away Toad Miasma."*

*Poem:*
The noxious vapors spread, unbearable their might,
Neighbors and lanes alike were filled with dread and fright.
By numinous power, the gales swept clean the air,
And peace was restored, the people’s health laid bare.

**Erecting a Shrine on Mushroom Isle**

chunks.original_text: 宋兴国八年癸未，春不雨。 祷王响应，诣祠求答。 忽有木炉捧出水心，双龙扶异，西流至屿山，横溪不进。 纸钱结界，异香袭人，夜现天灯之瑞。 乡人方珏，因以成其庙。 后产灵芝，号曰芝屿。 诗曰：神炉涌出绕双龙，扶翼西流止屿中。 夜现天灯诸瑞至，乡人因此立祠宫。 尊亲睦殿 神父讳温，吴拜为丞相。 天成丁亥卒，赠齐王，溢曰忠武。 母田氏讳淑，恭封仁寿仙妃。 及二王显灵立庙，先尊亲睦殿，序列唐王、洪王、鄂王、广陵王，皆神之兄也。 公、候、孙、子，皆王之仙眷也。 诗曰：二王庙食镇南闽，别构庭闱奉二亲。 雍睦衣冠如在日，编驱戏舞彩衣新。 立注生堂 夫人性禀谦柔质同坤。 重执勤后，德内助阴功。 江王妃许氏，讳珍，符封泾国夫人，顺助仁惠仙妃。 饶王妃陶氏，讳环韫，封卫国夫人，善助慈懿仙妃。 参东华法主，同授延生司注生司事。 诗曰：内助阴功政最明，一朝脱化得功成。
chunks.translated_text:
In the eighth year of Xingguo of the Song (983), spring brought no rain. Prayers to the king were swiftly answered, and the villagers approached the shrine to seek divine response. Suddenly, a wooden incense burner emerged from the water’s heart, borne aloft by twin dragons. It flowed westward to Mushroom Isle, where it halted, spanning the stream without advancing. Paper money marked the boundary, and an extraordinary fragrance filled the air. That night, celestial lanterns appeared as an auspicious sign. The villager Fang Jue thus established the shrine there. Later, when sacred lingzhi mushrooms grew upon the isle, it was named *Zhiyu* (Mushroom Isle).

*Poem:*
A divine censer rose, encircled by twin dragons,
Borne westward to rest upon the isle.
Celestial lanterns shone through the night, all omens fulfilled—
Thus the villagers built the shrine’s hall.

**Hall of Harmonious Kinship**
The divine father’s name was Wen, who served as Prime Minister under the Wu. He passed in the *dinghai* year of Tiancheng (927) and was posthumously enfeoffed as Prince Qi, with the posthumous title *Zhongwu* (Loyal and Martial). His mother, Lady Tian, named Shu, was reverently honored as the Immortal Consort *Renshou Xianfei* (Benevolent and Longevous). When the two princes manifested their divine power and the shrine was established, the Hall of Harmonious Kinship was first erected to honor them. Arrayed within were King Tang, King Hong, King E, and King Guangling—all elder brothers of the deities. Dukes, marquises, grandsons, and sons—all were the immortal kin of the kings.

*Poem:*
The twin kings’ shrine stands, guarding southern Min,
A separate hall built to honor their parents.
In harmonious robes, as if still living,
Processions and dances in vibrant new garments.

**Establishing the Hall of Life-Registration**
The lady’s nature was gentle and yielding, her virtue akin to Earth. She diligently upheld the duties of a wife, her inner power aiding in hidden merits. Consort Xu of Prince Jiang, named Zhen, was enfeoffed as Lady of Jing State and honored as the Immortal Consort *Shunzhu Renhui Xianfei* (Compliant and Benevolent). Consort Tao of Prince Rao, named Huanyun, was enfeoffed as Lady of Wei State and honored as the Immortal Consort *Shanzhu Ciyi Xianfei* (Kindly and Auspicious). Together, they received the Daoist precepts of the Eastern Flowery Law Lord and were jointly entrusted with the affairs of the Bureau of Life-Prolongation and the Bureau of Life-Registration.

*Poem:*
Her inner power in governance shone most clearly,
In one transformation, her merits were fulfilled.

**Establishment of the Hall of Life-Registration**
The art of Life-Registration was once transmitted by the Eastern Flowery Lord, hence the hall was built and so named.

**Celestial Edicts of the Heavenly Emperor**
In the first year of *Zhidao* of the Song (995 CE), the villagers established the Yellow Register Assembly. Suddenly, celestial music resounded through the heavens, and auspicious clouds swirled about. The Heavenly Emperor dispatched divine messengers to bestow edicts, enfeoffing the Prince of Jiang as *True Man of the Golden Portal* and the Prince of Rao as *True Man of the Jade Portal*, each with a sixteen-character title. The consorts Tao and Xu were honored as *Immortal Consorts*, and their divine parents were likewise granted celestial enfeoffment. Thus, the hagiographies of the Two Perfected Ones were completed.

*Poem:*
The Yellow Register banquet opened as music filled the skies,
Divine messengers bestowed edicts, their grace profound.
The twin portals’ fame endures through endless ages,
A household of pearls and jade receives Heaven’s seal.

**Divine Soldiers Defend the Realm**
When the Min native Liu Yi was stationed in Guizhou, bandits besieged the border. Yi silently prayed to the Twin Portals, and the bandits indeed retreated. Later, when Han Shizhong fought at Dayi Garrison and Wu Zhen at Heshang Plain, divine soldiers were dispatched to shield the nation. They manifested the numinous power of Mount Gong’s grasses and trees, making the enemy see a million iron-clad cavalry in strict formation—so daunting that the foe fled without battle.

*Poem:*
His might displayed in Guizhou, repelling the southern tribes,
The gods’ efficacy shown in the mountain’s grasses and trees.
With iron cavalry arrayed in the valleys,
The bandits were swiftly pacified.

**Founding of Longshou Palace**
In the seventh year of *Zhenghe* of the Song (1117 CE), a site was divined at Dragon’s Head, and a temple was erected. In the *guisi* year of the Yuan (1293 CE), Shen Jianweng and others restored it, while Fang Huan and Fang Wen further erected gate tablets. In the *gengyin* year (1350 CE), funds were raised for reconstruction, though it remained unfinished. In the *dingyou* year of *Yongle* of the Ming (1417 CE), an imperial edict expanded the grounds, and the temple was rebuilt anew. The court appointed Fang Wenzhao as the sacrificial officer to oversee its worship.

*Poem:*
Fujian’s southern land, mighty beneath Ao Peak,
Here the Dragon’s Head Palace was chosen and built.
For the nation’s great merit, imperial favor runs deep,
Honored with a temple, its blessings endless.

**Auspicious Response to Prayers for Rain**
In the seventh year of *Xuanhe* of the Song (1125 CE), autumn brought no rain. The fields withered, and the harvest was imperiled. Farmers and villagers joined hands, praying at the temple. Suddenly, clouds and mist filled the sky, and a torrential downpour followed. From afar, on the southern mountain, a divine dragon flickered into view, bearing a yellow banner emblazoned with golden characters. The year yielded a bountiful harvest, and the people rejoiced in peace.

*Poem:*
Drought parched the land, the fields lay barren,
Crops withered, no water to be found.
At the temple’s prayer, dragon-mist arose,
The yellow banner gleamed, comforting the farmers.

**Eradicating Locusts**
In the second year of *Jiading* of the Song (1209 CE), during the fifth lunar month, the fields’ grain had tasseled but not yet ripened when locusts swarmed the land, wreaking havoc. The people were helpless. The village elders gathered at the temple, burning incense and offering solemn prayers with blood-stained sincerity. The Two Immortals summoned swift thunder, fierce rain, and violent winds, blowing the pests to the ground, where they perished.

*Poem:*
The western fields’ millet stood tall,
When locusts arose in grim despair.
Great winds and thunder brought torrential rain,
The pests fell dead, filling the furrows.

**Divine Soldiers Tame the Flood**
The villagers had long ago built a temple by Yan Brook, but it fell into ruin. In the fifth month of the *wuzǐ* year of *Shaoding* of the Song (1228 CE), heavy rains caused the brook to swell violently, drowning the crops. The people were terrified, but suddenly, a thousand laborers appeared, wielding baskets and spades. They dredged the source and diverted the flow, and the waters ceased to threaten the people. Soon after, the laborers vanished—revealed to be divine soldiers.

*Poem:*
Yan Brook’s floods surged, drowning the fields,
The people stood helpless, filled with dread.
Suddenly, a thousand men bore their tools,
Only then did they know the gods had come.

**Imperial Edicts and Honors**
The Two Immortals had earlier received the Heavenly Emperor’s favor and edicts of honor, their deeds renowned in their time, vivid in the people’s memory. Yet as temple steles crumbled, their story faded. In the third year of *Duanping* of the Song (1236 CE), the villagers petitioned the court, and an imperial edict was issued, bestowing the sixteen-character titles. The entire temple received imperial grace. In the first year of *Jiaxi* (1237 CE), the temple was honored with the golden-script edict plaque *Lingji Palace*.

*Poem:*
The Heavenly edicts came long ago,
Their divine traces later memorialized to the throne.
The golden-script plaque *Lingji* bestowed,
Their fame eternal, never to fade.

**Imperial Command to Welcome the Deities**
